text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Afghanistan's Taleban militia has sealed the border with Pakistan at Torkham.
- President Farooq Leghari hoped that he would not have to dissolve the National Assembly (lower house) or sack governments in future.
- Pakistan's human rights record was quite poor last year as extra-judicial killings increased, a U.S. State Department report said.
- Pakistan Muslim League president Nawaz Sharif has said India and Pakistan should learn to live as good neighbours and resolve irritants such as the Kashmir issue.
- The caretaker government plans to disqualify a number of candidates including some front line leaders for the elections set on February 3.
- The government has announced a three-year (1997/1999) textile quota management policy that calls for abolishing all discretionary quotas, ensuring transparency and promoting value-added products.
- The government plans to deregulate the petroleum sector.
- The businessmen have asked the government to obtain a moratorium on foreign debt servicing for at least five years.
- Stocks reacted bullishly on Thursday on rejection of ousted prime minister Benazir Bhutto plea for restoration of her government.
- Iran would not insist on the passage of a gas pipeline to India through Pakistan if it is a security concern for Pakistan, said Iranian Ambassador Mehdi Akhundzadeh at a news conference.
- The Privatisation Commission is examining applications of 12 parties to pre-qualify them as prospective bidders for the Habib Credit and Exchange Bank.
